issue.title: UNIMPLEMENTED endpoints using java grpc

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -80,6 +80,17 @@ namespace triton { namespace server {
     return;                                         \
   } while (false)
 
+#define RETURN_AND_RESPOND_IF_RESTRICTED(REQ, API_KEY)                     \
+  do {                                                                     \
+    static auto const is_restricted_api = restricted_apis_.count(API_KEY); \
+    static auto const restricted_api = restricted_apis_.find(API_KEY);     \
comment.body:
NP, I am wondering now though if the ultimate would be a const local variable initialized from a fixed offset into a table .... I didn't realize the penalty of accessing a static ... may move to a fixed table because we don't need the flexibility of the map (we have a fixed set of categories to restrict)

https://stackoverflow.com/a/21033042

pull_request.title: Extending restricted api to http
pull_request.body:
Adding support for restricting access to http apis based on header key and value (similar to grpc restricted protocols)

- Refactored command line parsing to create a map of features to header key and values
- Added check to all Handle APIs

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -80,6 +80,17 @@ namespace triton { namespace server {
     return;                                         \
   } while (false)
 
+#define RETURN_AND_RESPOND_IF_RESTRICTED(REQ, API_KEY)                     \
+  do {                                                                     \
+    static auto const is_restricted_api = restricted_apis_.count(API_KEY); \
+    static auto const restricted_api = restricted_apis_.find(API_KEY);     \
comment.body: 💡 Got it! Don't do PRs late at night is what I am learning. The macro defined the `static auto const` in each of the functions thus making the variable easily predicted since it's checking a const string. Sorry for throwing you through the ringer on this. This is better than I first thought.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -80,6 +80,17 @@ namespace triton { namespace server {
     return;                                         \
   } while (false)
 
+#define RETURN_AND_RESPOND_IF_RESTRICTED(REQ, API_KEY)                     \
+  do {                                                                     \
+    static auto const is_restricted_api = restricted_apis_.count(API_KEY); \
+    static auto const restricted_api = restricted_apis_.find(API_KEY);     \
comment.body: What I am thinking about is once the program is running for a bit and we have two requests on two different APIs say, inference and model config, and both are checking to see if they are restricted. Is there a race condition in the storage of the `is_restricted_api` variable? Or is this per thread storage?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -80,6 +80,17 @@ namespace triton { namespace server {
     return;                                         \
   } while (false)
 
+#define RETURN_AND_RESPOND_IF_RESTRICTED(REQ, API_KEY)                     \
+  do {                                                                     \
+    static auto const is_restricted_api = restricted_apis_.count(API_KEY); \
+    static auto const restricted_api = restricted_apis_.find(API_KEY);     \
comment.body:
static initialization is now thread safe and happens only once:

https://stackoverflow.com/a/8102145 

the restricted_apis_ map is initialized at start up and then is constant - so no race condition with count and find being out of sync.

Since it's static auto const - it will be initialized once and if is_restricted_api() is false it will be a quick exit (no lookup). 

My hope would be the execution would be smart enough to optimize out the check afterwards via branch prediction ...

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -80,6 +80,17 @@ namespace triton { namespace server {
     return;                                         \
   } while (false)
 
+#define RETURN_AND_RESPOND_IF_RESTRICTED(REQ, API_KEY)                     \
+  do {                                                                     \
+    static auto const is_restricted_api = restricted_apis_.count(API_KEY); \
+    static auto const restricted_api = restricted_apis_.find(API_KEY);     \
comment.body:
Why static here? Would this have a race condition across threads? I don't usually use the `static` keyword; but it's definition under [storage duration](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/storage_duration) I think implies this.

I guess the compiler should be able to get the `is_restricted_api` to execute first and check it out of order from the `restricted_api`. I am having a hard time getting an example function to demonstrate this though. I like this a lot better than the previous iteration! 👍

issue.title: UNAVAILABLE: Internal: archive_read_open_filename() failed.
issue.body:
**Description**
Docker container with base image of triton:22.05-py3 fails to start with  archive_read_open_filename() failed.

**Triton Information**
Triton server 22.05

Are you using the Triton container or did you build it yourself?
Building new container with base image of triton:22.05-py3

**To Reproduce**
Create DockerFile with 
FROM nvcr.io/nvidia/tritonserver:22.05-py3

Describe the models (framework, inputs, outputs), ideally include the model configuration file (if using an ensemble include the model configuration file for that as well).

**Expected behavior**
The container with python backend should work when dockerise with base image
